importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the public received the updated preliminary NTSB report on Brett James' plane crash.
The date the plane crash occurred, which is central to understanding the timeline of events and the investigation into the incident.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The single day when the incident occurred, marking the exact moment of the crash and subsequent investigation.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight, resulting in the deaths of all three people on board.

James had requested a visual approach to runway 7 and was instructed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), but he failed to change the frequency and instead announced a 360-degree turn at 6,800 feet.
The air traffic controller attempted to communicate with James, but there were no further communications after he failed to respond to instructions.
The Cirrus SR22T aircraft did not show any mechanical faults, and the NTSB found no evidence of mechanical failure.
The incident highlights a possible communication error or procedural lapse in pilot-air traffic control coordination, raising concerns about aviation safety protocols in visual approaches.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with major music stars including Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board’s preliminary report indicates the aircraft, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' after James failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF) despite being instructed to do so. He announced a 360-degree turn at 6,800 feet, and after the controller attempted to communicate, there were no further transmissions. The plane flew over runway 7 and crashed, killing all three people on board. The NTSB found no mechanical failure in the aircraft, suggesting the crash resulted from a communication or procedural error during a visual approach.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, the NTSB said in a preliminary report
